description:
Brevibacterium celere is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Brevibacterium. It is a Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, non-motile, and aerobic bacterium. Brevibacterium celere is characterized by its ability to grow rapidly, which is reflected in its species name "celere," meaning "swift" or "fast" in Latin.

This bacterium is typically found in various environmental sources, such as soil, water, and even human skin. It is known for its ability to produce carotenoid pigments, which can range in color from yellow to orange, contributing to its distinctive appearance.

Brevibacterium celere is considered a non-pathogenic bacterium and is not typically associated with causing disease in humans or animals. However, it has been reported to be involved in the spoilage of certain food products, particularly dairy products, due to its ability to produce off-flavors and aromas.

The genome of Brevibacterium celere has been sequenced, providing insights into its genetic makeup and potential metabolic capabilities. Ongoing research on this species may further elucidate its ecological roles and potential applications in various biotechnological or industrial processes.
